decay.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to be slowly destroyed by a natural chemical process, or to make something do this
decay.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Her body was already starting to decay.
Most archaeological finds are broken, damaged, or decayed.
decay.translation[0].definitions[0].note: In everyday English, people usually say rot rather than decay when talking about food:
There was a smell of rotting vegetables.
decay.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: if buildings, structures, or areas decay, their condition gradually becomes worse
decay.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: Hundreds of historic buildings are being allowed to decay.
decay.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: if traditional beliefs, standards etc decay, people do not believe in them or support them anymore
decay.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: In Orthodox Europe, mass religion seems to have decayed less.
decay.translation[0].note_box[0].section: decay
to be slowly destroyed by a natural chemical process – use this especially about natural things such as wood or plants, or about teeth
The leaves decay and enrich the soil.
He had bad breath and decaying teeth.
The fabric slowly began to decay.
rot
to decay. Rot is less formal than decay and is more common in everyday English
The fruit was left to rot on the ground.
rotting teeth
Most of the wood under the paint had rotted.
the smell of rotting vegetation  (=decaying leaves and plants)
go off
if food goes off, it starts to smell bad and is no longer be safe to eat
I think the milk’s gone off.
The meat smells as if it's gone off.
spoil
if food spoils, it starts to decay, so that it is no longer safe to eat. Spoil is more formal and is less common in everyday British English than go off
Food left in the sun will quickly start to spoil.
go mouldy
to begin to have a soft green or black substance growing on the surface of the food, so that it is not good to eat anymore
Ugh, the cheese has gone mouldy!
decompose
to decay – use this especially about dead plants or flesh
leaves decomposing on the forest floor
putrefy
to decay and have a very bad smell – use this especially about flesh or plants
After two days, the body was already beginning to putrefy.
putrefying meat
biodegrade
to decay naturally into substances that do not harm the environment – use this especially about man-made materials and chemicals
Unlike many other materials, plastic does not biodegrade.
decay.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: the natural chemical change that causes the slow destruction of something
decay.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: old cars in various stages of decay
decay.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: the gradual destruction of buildings, structures etc because they have not been cared for
decay.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: During the war, the area fell into decay.
decay.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: the gradual destruction of ideas, beliefs, social or political systems etc
decay.translation[1].note_box[0].section: Bacteria stick to food and cause decay.
You can use a preservative on the wood to prevent further decay.
Eating too much sugar causes tooth decay.
Everything in our environment is subject to natural decay.
The natural processes of decay gradually destroys archaeological sites.
I couldn't see any signs of decay on the fruit.
